title: 110_hr3820
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Motor Vehicle Advanced Safety Technology Tax Act of 2007". Congress finds that commercial motor vehicle crashes are a major concern in the United States, especially with the increasing number of trucks and their role in transporting hazardous materials. A 2004 report showed that large truck crashes are more likely to result in fatalities compared to passenger cars. In 2005, 5,212 individuals died and 114,000 were injured in large truck-related crashes, totaling 25,533 fatalities from 2001 to 2005. These crashes not only result in human loss but also impose a significant economic cost on society. The Department of Transportation estimates that highway crashes cost society $230.6 billion a year. Investments in advanced safety technologies by vehicle suppliers and manufacturers aim to mitigate commercial motor vehicle crash scenarios. The goal is to reduce the traffic fatality rate to 1.0 per hundred million vehicle miles traveled by 2011. The accelerated deployment of advanced safety technologies on commercial motor vehicles can reduce injuries and fatalities on the roads. Congress aims to increase the adoption of these technologies by providing tax incentives to make them more affordable for businesses. The IRS Code is amended to include a new section providing a tax credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems. The IRS Code is amended to include a new section providing a tax credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems. The credit is 50% of the cost of qualified systems, with limitations of $1,500 per system, $3,500 per vehicle, and a maximum of $350,000 per taxpayer. The new IRS Code section offers a tax credit for qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety systems, covering 50% of the system cost with a maximum credit limit of $350,000 per taxpayer. The definition of a qualified system includes various safety features certified by the manufacturer before use. The new IRS Code section provides a tax credit for qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety systems, covering 50% of the system cost with a maximum credit limit of $350,000 per taxpayer. The system must be appropriate for the vehicle, function as designed, certified if not installed by the manufacturer, have its original use with the taxpayer, and allow for depreciation or amortization. The term 'qualified commercial vehicle' is defined for this purpose. The term 'qualified commercial vehicle' is defined as a highway motor vehicle used for commerce with a weight rating of 26,001 pounds or more, a seating capacity of at least 15 individuals, or expected to be used as a school bus or intercity/local bus. The curr_chunk defines terms related to vehicle safety systems, including brake stroke monitoring, lane departure warning, and collision warning systems. These systems help drivers maintain safe operation of their vehicles by alerting them to potential issues or hazards on the road. The curr_chunk defines terms related to vehicle safety systems, including warning systems and vehicle stability systems that intervene to prevent rollover or instability. Controlled groups are treated as a single taxpayer under specific sections. In applying section 52 to this section, section 1563 shall be applied without regard to certain subsections. Special rules include basis reduction for property eligible for a credit, recapture of credit benefits, disallowance of credit for certain properties, and conditions for qualified commercial vehicles with advanced safety systems. The section discusses the conditions for claiming a credit for qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety systems, including the requirement for the seller to disclose the credit amount to the buyer and the option for the taxpayer to elect not to take the credit. Supporting documentation is necessary for claiming the credit. The taxpayer can choose not to apply the credit for a qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system. Supporting documentation, including system type and purchase/installation dates, is required for claiming the credit. The section outlines amendments to the general business credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems, including certification requirements and termination dates. Conforming amendments are made to sections 1016(a) and 6501 of the tax code. The amendments to the general business credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems include changes to section 6501 of the tax code. The amendments made by this section regarding the credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems will apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act.
